title: 109_hr3558
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Amendments Act of 2005". The Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project, a key component of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program, flooded the fertile bottom land of the Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation, impacting the national economy. The flooding of the Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation by the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project greatly damaged the economy and cultural resources of the tribe, leading to the loss of homes and communities. Congress provided compensation to the tribe, but it was deemed inadequate, leading to the enactment of the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act created a trust fund for the tribe but did not provide additional compensation for members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam project. The purpose of this Act is to use the trust fund to compensate those members for their land loss. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act created a trust fund to compensate members for land loss due to the Oahe Dam project. The Act also aims to capitalize the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act created a trust fund to compensate members for land loss due to the Oahe Dam project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to ensure fair compensation for land acquired for the Oahe Dam and Reservation project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to ensure fair compensation for land acquired for the Oahe Dam and Reservation project, including defining the term "member landowner." The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to define "member landowner" as a Tribe member who owned land on the Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation acquired for the Oahe Dam project. The term "power program" refers to the program under the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. Additionally, the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund is amended. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act (Law 106-511; 114 Stat. 2365) is amended to require the Secretary of the Treasury to deposit 25 percent of the power program funds into the Fund starting from October 1, 2004, until the total amount deposited equals a specified amount. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to require the Secretary of the Treasury to deposit 25 percent of power program funds into a Fund until a specified total amount is reached, as described in paragraph (2) detailing the calculation of the amount. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to calculate interest using the Lehman Government Bond Index or a similar index determined by the Secretary of the Treasury in consultation with the Tribal Council. The amendment also changes the starting date for certain provisions to October 1, 2005. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to provide additional compensation to member landowners for land acquisition by the United States for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. This includes provisions for processing claims of heirs of member landowners. The Secretary of the Interior must provide requested records to the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe within 60 days to identify heirs of member landowners affected by the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Tribe and member landowners are eligible for additional compensation under the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act.
